CAPITOL SHOOTING EXPOSES CRACKS IN MENTAL-HEALTH CARE SYSTEM 

  
 (ATTN: Ill., Mont., N.Y., Va.)  (Eds: In second sentence of 8th graph adds number of mentally ill
persons held in jail each day. No other changes.) (Eds: See also
CAPITOL-SHOOTING-RDP) 
(js) 
 By FOX BUTTERFIELD   
 c.1998 N.Y. Times News Service   

   BOSTON _ Russell Weston Jr., the suspect in the fatal shootings
of two police officers in the nation's Capitol, may have chosen an
unusually public place to explode. But his history of mental
illness has much in common with other delusional mentally ill
people who become violent, illustrating both the cracks in the
nation's mental-health system and its difficulty in mandating
treatment even for those it knows could become violent.

   Weston's illness was well-known to family and mental health
officials. But because of the closing of state mental hospitals
across the country and the failure to build a promised network of
local clinics, the treatment of choice for him, as for the vast
majority of mental patients, was the honor system: counting on him
to give himself the often unpleasant antipsychotic drugs prescribed
for his paranoid schizophrenia.

   With Weston, the problem was compounded by living in rural areas
where psychiatric treatment and monitoring are extremely limited.
He also traveled between two states, Montana and Illinois,
encouraging at least one to solve his long-term care by sending him
back to the other.

   When Weston became violent, the reasons behind his behavior were
typical of the small group of mentally ill people who become
violent, recent research shows. He was not taking his medication,
he may have been using other drugs, and he had paranoid delusions _
in his case that the government was out to get him, using satellite
dishes aimed at his cabin or assigning Navy Seals and CIA
operatives to pursue him.

   Dr. E. Fuller Torrey, a psychiatrist and president of the
Treatment Advocacy Center in Arlington, Va. , said ``Mr. Weston is
an absolutely textbook case of what some of us have been saying for
years'' _ the dangers inherent in leaving untreated someone with
paranoid schizophrenia who does not understand he is ill.

   He estimated that there are about 100,000 people with
schizophrenia nationwide who are not being treated.

   The problem is preventable, Torrey said, given the development
of powerful drugs that can stabilize patients with severe mental
illnesses. In the 1960s states began to close mental hospitals
because the drugs offered a more humane _ and less expensive _ way
to treat the mentally ill in their communities. That approach,
however, required a network of community clinics to make sure
patients took the drugs, and those clinics were not built.

   As a result, many people with schizophrenia, manic-depression
and severe depression stop taking their drugs and regress. Every
day 200,000 are held in jails or prisons because of the bizarre
behavior that results.

   Torrey's advocacy group seeks to improve treatment of the
seriously mentally ill and to change laws that make it difficult to
commit mental patients against their will.

   Such problems exist throughout most of the country. In
Westchester County, N.Y., in June, Michael Laudor, a Yale Law
School graduate who had won book and movie deals for the story of
his successful battle against schizophrenia, was charged with
stabbing his fiance to death. His medications had become
ineffective, friends said, but he had not been hospitalized.

   The mental-health net is especially weak in rural areas, where
the nearest psychiatrist may be 100 miles away and there is often
an aversion to government spending.

   In Montana, where Weston lived in a cabin over much of the past
20 years, ``It is so hard to get psychiatric treatment you usually
have to get arrested to get treatment,'' said Wesley Alcorn, a
member of the state board of the National Alliance for the Mentally
Ill, a group made up of relatives and friends of mentally ill
people.

   In fact, under Montana law, for a person to be committed to the
state hospital at Warm Springs, he must pose an imminent threat to
himself or others, ``which is usually interpreted to mean he must
be pointing a gun at himself or someone else,'' Alcorn said. Many
people with mental disorders are simply put in the local jail, he
said.

   (STORY CAN END HERE. OPTIONAL MATERIAL FOLLOWS)

   A judge committed Weston to the Warm Springs hospital for 53
days in 1996, apparently after Weston made a threat against
President Clinton and was interviewed by the Secret Service.

   After being placed on medication, he was released on Dec. 2,
1996, because the hospital ``deemed him no longer a threat to
himself or others,'' according to a spokesman for Gov. Marc
Racicot. A hospital employee drove him to his cabin in nearby
Rimini, the spokesman said, and made arrangements for him to
receive further treatment at a mental health center in Waterloo,
Ill., near his parents' rural home outside Valmeyer in southern
Illinois.

   Alcorn described this as ``Greyhound therapy,'' a way to save
Montana money by buying Weston a one-way bus ticket for a trip out
of the state.

   In a series of interviews on Sunday, Weston's parents and
sister, April Callahan, said that he returned to Illinois with
three medications (whose names they did not remember) and that he
stopped taking them about a week later, despite his family's
protests. While his family described their growing concern over his
paranoid delusions, they also seemed to understand little about how
to seek help for him, or what treatment was available.

   The only community mental health clinic in Waterloo is Human
Support Services, a state-funded center. A spokesman for the
clinic, Rob Singer, refused to say on Monday whether Weston had
been a client there after his return from Montana.

   Torrey said people like Weston would be less likely to fall
through the cracks if states like Montana and Illionois used
existing laws that provide for involuntary outpatient treatment.
Such laws allow states to force a patient to take his medication if
he fails to show up for appointments at a local clinic or stops
taking his medication.

   Preventing a shooting like that attributed to Weston is
particularly difficult because the relationship between mental
illness and violence is very sensitive, and many experts have been
cautious about publicizing new research suggesting that in certain
situations the emotionally disturbed are more violent than other
people.

   Such situations occur when mentally ill persons have strong
paranoid symptoms that someone is out to get them or hear a voice
telling them to kill, said Bruce Link, a professor at Columbia
University School of Public Health. Another is when a patient fails
to show up for treatment or is off his medication, said Jeffrey
Sawnson, an assistant professor of psychiatry at Duke University.

   Last May, a MacArthur Foundation study found that mental
patients are no more violent than others unless they are abusing
drugs or alcohol. And Swanson said it is important to remember that
the mentally ill are responsible for only about 4 percent of
overall violence, making mental illness a smaller risk factor for
violence than being young, male or poor. But in a sign of how the
experts disagree on the subject, Torrey stressed that mentally ill
people commit 1,000 homicides a year.
